comment._content:
John Willoughby Scott was the son of Sir John Scott KCMG DCI and Lady Scott, and was married to Madeline E Scott, of Tudor Cottage, Overthorpe, Banbury, Oxfordshire. He was educated at Rugby School.

From 'The Great War Forum': an extract from the 8th SLI War Diary during the Second Battle of the Scarpe 23-24 April 1917.

The 8th Somerset L.I. meanwhile had collected their main body in the sunken road south of the X roads in I 7 1. under the command of Captain Saunders and 2nd Lt Owen:- the only two Officers who remained in action until relieved. Lt Col J W Scott, his Adjutant, Headqrs, and the remainder of the Battalion were at about I 7 1.1. At this stage the Adjutant was wounded, and Lt Col J W Scott was killed, while the enemy in artillery formation came down over GREENLAND HILL to a trench about 800 yards of the sunken road running from the I 7 a 2.8 to I 7 c.7.8 and parallel to it.//

comment.author: 29296338@N07
comment._content: As Captain John Willoughby Scott, he sailed with the Queen's Own Oxfordshire Hussars to France on 20th September 1914 as squadron leader of "A" (Oxford) Squadron having seen service in the South African War in the Royal Artillery.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
John Willoughby Scott was awarded a Distinguished Service Order, DSO, for meritorious service in the King's Birthday Honours List of 1 Jan 1917; he was also 3 times Mentioned in Despatches.

John Willoughby Scott was originally commissioned from the Royal Military Academy as a Second Lieutenant on 23 Dec 1897. [LG 18 Jan 1898].

His Territorial Force commission as a Captain in the Oxfordshire (Queen's Own Oxfordshire) Hussars reverted to Second Lieutenant in receipt of retired pay under Article 510 of the Royal Warrant on 23 May 1908 [LG 1 Dec 1908].//
